January 29, 2006: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A murder at the Louvre
leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a secret
society.
THE HOSTAGE, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer probes the
murder of an American diplomat and the kidnapping of his wife, whose brother is linked
to the Iraq oil-for-food scandal.
THE CAT WHO DROPPED A BOMBSHELL, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam,
$23.95.) The columnist Jim Qwilleran and his cats investigate the mysterious death of a
wealthy couple.
“S” IS FOR SILENCE, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95.) Kinsey Millhone
searches for a woman who disappeared 34 years ago.
MARY, MARY, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The F.B.I. agent Alex Cross
tracks a Hollywood killer who announces the crimes via e-mail.
EVERY BREATH YOU TAKE, by Judith McNaught. (Ballantine, $25.95.) When the
grandson of a Chicago philanthropist disappears, suspicion falls on the wrong man.
AT FIRST SIGHT, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.95.) The young couple from "True
Believer," who are now expecting a child, receive a disturbing message.
TURNING ANGEL, by Greg Iles. (Scribner, $25.95.) To defend a friend wrongly
accused of murder, a Mississippi lawyer must investigate the secret lives of local prep
school students.
JUST REWARDS, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Concluding the
story of the Harte family and its financial empire, told through four generations of
women.
ON THE RUN, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $26.) A little girl and her mother, a gifted
horse trainer who once worked for the C.I.A., are targeted by a Middle Eastern magnate.
CHRIST THE LORD: OUT OF EGYPT, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $25.95.) What happened
in Bethlehem; a story narrated by a 7-year-old who discovers that he is the Prince of
Peace.
ALL NIGHT LONG, by Jayne Ann Krentz. (Putnam, $24.95.) A journalist returns to her
Northern California hometown to investigate the death of an old friend and the murder of
her parents years before.
PREDATOR, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) On the trail of a possible serial
killer, Dr. Kay Scarpetta turns to a jailed psychopath for advice.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An
January 29, 2006
Non-Fiction
FOR LACI, by Sharon Rocha. (Crown, $25.95.) Laci Peterson's mother recalls her
daughter and describes her killer's trial.
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and
his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
MY FRIEND LEONARD, by James Frey. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The author of the
addiction memoir "A Million Little Pieces" remembers a helpful mobster friend.
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.)
A columnist for The New York Times analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign
policy and presents an overview of globalization trends.
THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, by Joan Didion. (Knopf, $23.95.) The
author's attempts to come to terms with the death of her husband and the grave
illness of their only daughter.
TEACHER MAN, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) The author of "Angela's
Ashes" remembers his years teaching high school English in New York City.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
OUR ENDANGERED VALUES, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The
former president warns against blurring politics and fundamentalist religion.
TEAM OF RIVALS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) The
political genius of Abraham Lincoln, revealed in his relationship with his cabinet,
from the author of "No Ordinary Time."
STATE OF WAR, by James Risen. (Free Press, $26.) The secret history of the
C.I.A. and the Bush administration.
1776, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) An account of America's
founding year by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, focusing on the inexperienced
George Washington and heroic citizen soldiers.
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
THE NUMBER, by Lee Eisenberg. (Free Press, $26.) How to think about the
amount of money you need to live the way you want to after you retire.
SEX AND THE SEASONED WOMAN, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $25.95.)
The author of "Passages" describes women over 50 who have vital sex lives.
